contentrichtext.text: {{other uses2|Balbus}} {{one source|date=February 2012}} {{no footnotes|date=February 2012}} '''Balbus''', literally "[[stammer]]er", was a [[cognomen]] of several [[ancient Roman]] [[gens|gentes]]. Of the [[Acilia (gens)|Acilii]] [[Balbi]], one [[Manius Acilius Balbus]] was consul in 150 BC, another in 114 BC. To another family belonged T. Ampius Balbus, a supporter of [[Pompey]], but afterwards pardoned by [[Julius Caesar]] (cf. [[Cicero|Cic.]] ''ad Fam.'' vi. 12 and xiii. 70). We know also of Q. Antonius Balbus, [[praetor]] in [[Sicily]] in 82 BC, and [[Marcus Atius Balbus]], who married [[Juliae Caesares (sisters of Julius Caesar)|Julia]], a sister of Caesar, and had a daughter [[Atia Balba Caesonia|Atia]], mother of [[Augustus]]. The most important of the name were the two Cornelii Balbi, natives of Gades ([[CÃ¡diz]]): *[[Lucius Cornelius Balbus (major)]] *[[Lucius Cornelius Balbus (minor)]] Others with the cognomen include: * [[Marcus Atius Balbus]] (105 BC-51 BC) * [[Decius Laelius Balbus]] (c. 6 BC) * [[Gaius Norbanus]] Balbus (died c. 81 BC), Roman consul * [[Quintus Bruttius Balbus]], of the ''[[gens]] [[Bruttia (gens)|Bruttia]]'' * [[Manius Acilius Balbus]], of the ''[[Acilia (gens)|gens Acilia]]'' * [http://books.google.ca/books?id=OmgCAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA487&hl=fr Thorius Balbus] (c. 111 BC), author of the agrarian law known as the ''Thoria Lex'' ==References== *{{1911}} {{surname|Balbus}} [[Category:Ancient Roman families]] [[Category:Prosopography of Ancient Rome]] [[Category:Ancient Roman cognomina]]
